facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 167 of 1955 was an appeal by special leave in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 167 of 1955. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 22, 1951,

facts.text: Nagpur High Court passed judgment and decree dated November 22, 1951 in Second Appeal No. 720 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 22, 1951, of the former Nagpur High Court in Second Appeal No. 720 of 1945. N. Kherdekar, N. K. Kherdekar and A. G. Ratna.

facts.text: High Court confirmed the decree of the District Judge in second appeal No. 1720 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: High Court at Nagpur passed in second appeal No. 1720 of 1945 confirming the decree of the District Judge. In the suit out of which this appeal has arisen the appellant was defendant No. 1 and the respondents were the plaintiff and defendant Nos. 2 and 3

facts.text: Appellant was defendant No. 1, respondents were plaintiff and defendants Nos. 2 and 3 in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the suit out of which this appeal has arisen the appellant was defendant No. 1 and the respondents were the plaintiff and defendant Nos. 2 and 3 and the dispute relates to pre-emption on the ground of co-occupancy which falls under Ch. XIV of the Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928, hereinafter called the Code.

facts.text: Dispute relates to pre-emption on ground of co-occupancy under Ch. XIV of Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents were the plaintiff and defendant Nos. 2 and 3 and the dispute relates to pre-emption on the ground of co-occupancy which falls under Ch. XIV of the Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928, hereinafter called the Code. On April 10, 1943, D. B. Ghaisas and his mother Ramabai entered into two contracts of sale with the appellant,

facts.text: On April 10, 1943, D. B. Ghaisas and mother Ramabai entered two contracts of sale with appellant: one for Survey Nos. 5,14,16 for Rs.10,000 (earnest Rs.2,000); other for Survey No.15/1 for Rs.8,500 (earnest Rs.500).

anchor.surface_text: On April 10, 1943, D. B. Ghaisas and his mother Ramabai entered into two contracts of sale with the appellant, one in regard to Survey Nos. 5, 14 and 16 for a sum of Rs. 10,000 out of which Rs. 2,000 was paid as earnest money and the other in regard to Survey No. 15/1 for Rs. 8,500 out of which Rs. 500 was paid as earnest money.

facts.text: On April 16, 1943, vendors executed registered sale deed for Survey Nos. 5,14,16 and balance price paid before Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: On April 16, 1943, the vendors executed a registered sale deed in regard to Survey No,. 5, 14 and 16 and the balance of the price was paid before the Registrar. On April 22, 1943, the vendors executed a lease of Survey No. 15/1 for 14 years in favour of Kisanlal and Sitaram who were defendant Nos. 2 and 3 in the suit and are respondents Nos. 2 and 3 in this appeal.

facts.text: On April 22, 1943, vendors executed 14-year lease of Survey No.15/1 to Kisanlal and Sitaram (defendants 2 and 3, respondents 2 and 3).

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1943, the vendors executed a lease of Survey No. 15/1 for 14 years in favour of Kisanlal and Sitaram who were defendant Nos. 2 and 3 in the suit and are respondents Nos. 2 and 3 in this appeal. On April 24, 1943, the vendors executed a fresh agreement of sale in respect of the same field which according to the agreement was to be diverted to non- agricultural purposes

facts.text: On April 24, 1943, vendors executed fresh agreement of sale for Survey No.15/1 to be diverted to non-agricultural, appellant to pay diversion costs and premium.

anchor.surface_text: On April 24, 1943, the vendors executed a fresh agreement of sale in respect of the same field which according to the agreement was to be diverted to non- agricultural purposes and thereafter a sale deed was to be executed when it was so diverted. The appellant was to pay the costs of the diversion as well as the premium.

facts.text: On August 12, 1943, vendors applied to Deputy Commissioner, Akola for diversion under s.58 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this agreement the vendors applied to the Deputy Commissioner, Akola, on August 12, 1943, for diver- sion under s. 58 of the Code and sanction was accorded on January 22, 1944, subject to payment of premium of Rs. 9,222 and other conditions.

facts.text: On January 22, 1944, sanction for diversion accorded subject to premium of Rs.9,222.

anchor.surface_text: for diver- sion under s. 58 of the Code and sanction was accorded on January 22, 1944, subject to payment of premium of Rs. 9,222 and other conditions. The appellants case is that as agreed the vendors were paid this money for deposit and it was deposited in the Treasury under Challan No. 68 but there is no finding in favour of the appellant

facts.text: Appellant claims vendors were paid premium for deposit, deposited via Challan No.68; no finding by courts but proceeded on premise.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case is that as agreed the vendors were paid this money for deposit and it was deposited in the Treasury under Challan No. 68 but there is no finding in favour of the appellant although the trial court and the District Judge seem to have proceeded on the premises that this amount was deposited but in the cir- cumstances of this case it is not necessary to go into this matter.

facts.text: On February 1, 1944, sale deed executed by vendors in favour of appellant for Survey No.15/1, consideration Rs.17,722.

anchor.surface_text: On February 1, 1944, the sale deed was executed by the vendors in favour of the appellant and the consideration in the sale deed was Rs. 17,722. On September 11, 1943, i.e., before the sale deed was executed the respondent, Sridhar, brought a suit for pre- emption against the appellant on the allegation that he had a co-occupancy in the Survey number in dispute-being the owner of Survey No. 15/2.

facts.text: On September 11, 1943, respondent Sridhar filed suit for pre-emption against appellant, alleging co-occupancy as owner of Survey No.15/2.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1943, i.e., before the sale deed was executed the respondent, Sridhar, brought a suit for pre- emption against the appellant on the allegation that he had a co-occupancy in the Survey number in dispute-being the owner of Survey No. 15/2. In the plaint it was alleged that the transaction of contract under the documents of April 10, 1943, and April 24, 1943, constituted a sale and therefore it was subject to respondent Sridhars prior right of pre- emption.

facts.text: Respondent alleged April 10 and 24, 1943 contracts constituted a sale subject to pre-emption; price not fixed in good faith. Allegations denied by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it was alleged that the transaction of contract under the documents of April 10, 1943, and April 24, 1943, constituted a sale and therefore it was subject to respondent Sridhars prior right of pre- emption. It was also alleged that the price was not fixed in good faith. These allegations were denied.

facts.text: Trial court and District Judge held Sridhar entitled to pre-empt, fair consideration Rs.3,306; decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial court and the District Judge held that respondent Sridhar was entitled to preempt and determined the fair consideration to be Rs. 3,306. The suit was therefore decreed by the trial court and on appeal by the District Judge.

facts.text: High Court confirmed decrees of subordinate courts; held transaction was sale subject to pre-emption, failure to execute deed was subterfuge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that the transaction was a sale which was subject to pre-emption and that the failure to execute and register a sale deed was a subterfuge to defeat the right of pre-emption. It also hold that the proceedings taken for conversion of agricultural land into non- agricultural land were pendente lite

facts.text: High Court held diversion proceedings pendente lite, right accrued; Sub-Divisional Officer order conditional, land not irrevocably diverted.

anchor.surface_text: and as the right of preemption had already accrued by subsequent acts of the vendors and the vendee it could not be defeated. The High Court further held that as the order of the Sub-Divisional Officer allowing conversion was a conditional one the land could not be said to have been irrevocably diverted to non- agricultural purposes.

facts.text: Berar ceded by Nizam to British in 1853; Mohammedan pre-emption rule allegedly in force till Berar Land Revenue Code 1896 from Jan 1, 1897.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to the cession of Berar by the Nizam of Hyderabad to the British Government in 1853, the Mohammedan rule of preemption was, according to one view, in force in the province of Berar and it continued to be so till the Berar Land Revenue Code of 1896 came into operation as from January 1, 1897.

facts.text: Transfer of Property Act extended to Berar in 1907.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1907 the Transfer of Property Act IV of 1882 was extended to the province of Berar. In 1928, the Code was re-enacted and it further extended the provisions in regard to pre-emption in Ch. XIV.

facts.text: Berar Land Revenue Code re-enacted in 1928.

anchor.surface_text: In 1928, the Code was re-enacted and it further extended the provisions in regard to pre-emption in Ch. XIV. Under s. 174 pre-emptive rights arise in respect of transfers of unalienated land held for agricultural purposes

facts.text: Respondent Sridhar is owner of Survey No.15/2.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent, Sridhar, brought a suit for pre- emption against the appellant on the allegation that he had a co-occupancy in the Survey number in dispute-being the owner of Survey No. 15/2.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 23, 1960 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: According to s. 2 of the Transfer of Property Act which at the relevant time was in operation in Berar s. 54 is not one of the sections within ch. 2 of that Act and therefore it overrides Mohammedan law and the provisions of that section, being exhaustive as to modes of transfer, govern all sales in that province and no title passes on a sale except as provided in that section. Sale is there defined as transfer of ownership for a price paid or promised or part paid or part promised and in the case of sale of tangible immoveable property of Rs. 100/- or more sale can only be made by a registered instrument.

concepts.interpretation: Defines sale as requiring registered instrument for immovable property over Rs.100; no title passes on mere contract; overrides personal law for transfers; pre-emption does not arise until registered sale

outcome.relief_summary: No right of pre-emption arose or could be enforced because the suit was filed before the registered sale deed was executed and no transfer of title had occurred under s. 54 of the Transfer of Property Act; lower courts erred in decreeing the pre-emption suit.
